title:
Speed of convergence in the Central Limit Theorem for the determinantal
  point process with the Bessel kernel

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We consider a family of linear operators, diagonalized by the Hankel transform. The Fredholm determinants of these operators, restricted to $L_{2}[0, R]$, are expressed in a convenient form for asymptotic analysis as $R \rightarrow \infty$. The result is an identity, in which the determinant is equal to the leading asymptotic multiplied by an asymptotically small factor, for which an explicit formula is derived. We apply the result to the determinantal point process with the Bessel kernel, calculating the speed of the convergence of additive functionals with respect to the Kolmogorov-Smirnov metric.

## 1 Introduction

For $f \in L_{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right) \cap L_{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)$consider the kernel

$$
B_{f}(x, y)=\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} t \sqrt{x y} J_{\nu}(x t) J_{\nu}(y t) f(t) d t
$$

where $J_{\nu}$ is a Bessel function of order $\nu$. Let us fix $\nu>-1$. The kernel (1.1) induces a bounded linear operator on $L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)$, which we will also denote by $B_{f}$. In addition, we let $B_{1}$ be the identity operator. We will refer to the kernel (1.1) and the operator $B_{f}$ as the Bessel kernel and the Bessel operator.

For any $h \in L_{\infty}(X)$ we also let $h$ stand for the operator of pointwise multiplication on $L_{2}(X)$. Let $\chi_{A}(x)$ be the characteristic function of the subset $A$.

In the following work we consider the Fredholm determinant $\operatorname{det}\left(I+\chi_{[0, R]} B_{f} \chi_{[0, R]}\right)$ for $R>0$ and sufficiently smooth function $f$. The determinant gives an exact expression for the Laplace transform of additive functionals in the determinantal point process with the Bessel kernel (see [26]). We describe the relation between the determinantal point process and the operator in Section 5. Briefly, the operator $B_{\chi_{[0,1]}}$ induces a probability measure $\mathbb{P}_{J_{\nu}}$ on countable subsets of $\mathbb{R}_{+}$without accumulation points. The subsets, called configurations, are endowed with certain $\sigma$-algebra (see [25]). For any measurable function $b$ on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$the additive functional is defined to be a measurable function on configurations by the formula $S_{b}(X)=\sum_{x \in X} b(x)$. The probability measure induces the random variable $S_{b}$. For $b \in L_{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right) \cap L_{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)$we have that the Laplace transform of $S_{b}$ is expressed by the formula

$$
\mathbb{E}_{J_{\nu}} e^{\lambda S_{b}}=\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0,1]} B_{e^{\lambda b}} \chi_{[0,1]}\right)
$$

For the function $b$ we consider the additive functional $S_{b}^{R}=S_{b(x / R)}$ as $R \rightarrow \infty$. For the dilated function we have

$$
\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0,1]} B_{e^{\lambda b(x / R)}} \chi_{[0,1]}\right)=\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0, R]} B_{e^{\lambda b}} \chi_{[0, R]}\right)
$$

We conclude that the limit distribution of $S_{b}^{R}$ can be derived via asymptotic of the determinant.
Let us recall an analogous problem for the sine process $\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{S}}$. Unlike the Bessel kernel determinantal point process, it is a measure on configurations on the real line $\mathbb{R}$. The measure is induced by an operator on $L_{2}(\mathbb{R})$ with the integral kernel $K_{\mathcal{S}}(x, y)=\frac{\sin \pi(x-y)}{\pi(x-y)}$. The formula for the Laplace transform for $b \in L_{1}(\mathbb{R}) \cap L_{\infty}(\mathbb{R})$ in this case is

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{S}} e^{\lambda S_{b}^{R}}=\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0,2 \pi R]} W_{e^{\lambda b}} \chi_{[0,2 \pi R]}\right)
$$

where $W_{e^{\lambda b}}$ is a Wiener-Hopf operator with symbol $e^{\lambda b}$, which we define in the following section. For these determinants we recall two results. First one is the Kac-Akhiezer formula [10, Sect. 10.13], which states that under certain conditions on $b$ we have

$$
\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0,2 \pi R]} W_{e^{\lambda b}} \chi_{[0,2 \pi R]}\right)=\exp \left(\lambda R c_{1}^{\mathcal{S}}(b)+\lambda^{2} c_{2}^{\mathcal{S}}(b)\right) Q_{R}^{\mathcal{S}}(\lambda b)
$$

where $Q_{R}^{\mathcal{S}}(\lambda b) \rightarrow 1$ as $R \rightarrow \infty$. See Theorem 3.1 for the values of $c_{1}^{\mathcal{S}}(b), c_{2}^{\mathcal{S}}(b)$. We note that the distribution approaches Gaussian if $c_{1}^{\mathcal{S}}(b)=0$. The second result is an exact formula for the remainder term $Q_{R}^{\mathcal{S}}(\lambda b)$, see again Theorem 3.1. These results are continuous analogues of the Strong Szegö Limit Theorem and the Borodin-Okounkov identity for Toeplitz matrices (see [10, Sect. 10.4] for the former and [11] for the latter result). Borodin and Okounkov first derived the expression for determinants of Toeplitz matrices via the Gessel theorem and Schur measures. Several different proves under less restrictive assertions were given later [6], [9]. These approaches may be applied in the continuous case, it was done by Basor and Chen in [2]. Another proof in the continuous case under weaker assumptions was given by Bufetov in [12].

Having derived a formula for $Q_{R}^{\mathcal{S}}(\lambda b)$, it is possible to estimate the speed of the convergence of $S_{b}^{R}$, which was done by Bufetov in [13, Lemma 3.10]. Theorem 2.2 gives a similar estimate for the Bessel kernel point process.

An analogue of the Kac-Akhiezer formula in case of the Bessel kernel is derived by Basor and Ehrhardt in [3]. We state it in Theorem 8.4. Again, the distribution of additive functionals approaches Gaussian if $c_{1}^{R}(b)=0$. In this paper we will derive an exact expression for $Q_{R}^{R}(\lambda b)$, therefore proving an analogue of the exact identity, and estimate its speed of convergence.

The result has two special cases $\nu= \pm 1 / 2$. In these cases the Bessel operator (1.1) is known to be the sum of the Wiener-Hopf and Hankel operators:

$$
B_{f}=W_{f} \pm H_{f}, \quad \text { if } \nu=\mp 1 / 2
$$

where $H_{f}$ is a Hankel integral operator with kernel $\chi_{[0, \infty)^{2}}(x, y) \hat{f}(x+y)$. The value of $Q_{R}^{R}(b)$ for these cases was derived by Basor, Ehrhardt and Widom in [5]. Our result - Theorem 2.1 reproduces their formula. It is notable that in these cases $B_{f}$ has a discrete analogue: a sum of Toeplitz and Hankel matrices. An analogue of the Szegö theorem for the latter has been proved by Johansson [18]. Furthermore, there is a counterpart of the Borodin-Okounkov formula for these matrices, derived by Basor and Ehrhardt in [4] via operator-theoretic methods. Another proof, similar to the one of Borodin and Okounkov for Toeplitz matrices, has been given by Betea [8], who used symplectic and orthogonal Schur measures.

Lastly, let us recall that an analogous problem of rate of convergence of additive functionals has already been considered for random matrix ensembles. E. g., classical compact groups were studied by Johansson in [18]. In [19] authors considered traces of random Haar-distributed matrices multiplied by a deterministic one. Lambert, Ledoux and Webb studied the speed of the convergence in $\beta$-ensembles with respect to the Wasserstein-2 distance in [20]. Gaussian Laguerre and Jacobi ensembles were studied by Bufetov and Berezin in [7] via Deift-Zhou asymptotic analysis of Riemann-Hilbert problem [14]. The authors of [1] studied convergence of additive functionals in Wigner ensembles. However, the mentioned ensembles are finite-dimensional, with number of points growing in the considered limit. On the other hand, the Bessel kernel point process is a measure on infinite configurations. Therefore, we pursue the operator-theoretic approach used in [2] and [3].

# 2 Statement of the result 

For a function $f \in L_{1}(\mathbb{R}) \cap L_{\infty}(\mathbb{R})$ define the Fourier transform by the formula

$$
\hat{f}(\lambda)=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}} e^{-i \lambda x} f(x) d x
$$

Here and subsequently if $f$ is defined on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$we extend it evenly. In this case the Fourier transform coincides with the cosine transform. Define the Sobolev $p$-seminorm of a function $f$ on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$as follows

$$
\|f\|_{\dot{H}_{p}}^{2}=\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}}|\hat{f}(\lambda)|^{2}|\lambda|^{2 p} d \lambda
$$

For an integer $p$ it is equal to $(2 \pi)^{-1 / 2}\left\|f^{(p)}\right\|_{L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)}$by the Parseval theorem. Denote $\|f\|_{H_{p}}=$ $\|f\|_{L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)}+\|f\|_{\dot{H}_{p}}$ and define the Sobolev space $H_{p}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)=\left\{f \in L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right):\|f\|_{H_{p}}<+\infty\right\}$ to be a Banach space with the norm $\|\cdot\|_{H_{p}}$. The Sobolev space $H_{p}(\mathbb{R})$ on the real line is defined similarly, we keep the same notation for norms.

Define the following seminorm for a function $f$ on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$

$$
\|f\|_{\mathcal{B}}=\|f\|_{\dot{H}_{1}}+\|f\|_{\dot{H}_{3}}+\|x f(x)\|_{\dot{H}_{2}}+\left\|x^{2} f(x)\right\|_{\dot{H}_{3}}
$$

Again denote $\|f\|_{\mathcal{B}}=\|f\|_{L_{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)}+\|f\|_{L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)}+\|x f(x)\|_{L_{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)}+\|f\|_{\mathcal{B}}$ and define the space

$$
\mathcal{B}=\left\{f \in L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right):\|f\|_{\mathcal{B}}<+\infty\right\}
$$

to be a Banach space with the norm $\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{B}}$.
For a function $f \in L_{\infty}(\mathbb{R})$ the Wiener-Hopf operator on $L_{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)$is defined by the formula

$$
W_{f}=\chi_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} \mathcal{F} f \mathcal{F}^{-1} \chi_{\mathbb{R}_{+}}
$$

where $\mathcal{F}$ is the unitary Fourier transform on $L_{2}(\mathbb{R}): \mathcal{F} h=\sqrt{2 \pi} h, h \in L_{2}(\mathbb{R})$. Again, if $f$ is defined on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$, extend it evenly.

Denote

$$
P_{ \pm}=\mathcal{F}^{-1} \chi_{\mathbb{R}_{ \pm}} \mathcal{F}, \quad H_{1}^{ \pm}(\mathbb{R})=P_{ \pm}\left(H_{1}(\mathbb{R})\right)
$$

Then $H_{1}(\mathbb{R})=H_{1}^{+}(\mathbb{R}) \oplus H_{1}^{-}(\mathbb{R})$. For any function $b \in H_{1}(\mathbb{R})$ denote $b_{ \pm}=P_{ \pm} b, b=b_{+}+b_{-}$. The introduced space $\mathcal{B}$ is clearly a subspace of $H_{1}(\mathbb{R})$ with embedding given by even continuation, so the decomposition is well defined on $\mathcal{B}$, although the components may fail to remain in $\mathcal{B}$. We will refer to such decomposition as to Wiener-Hopf factorization.

The main result is then stated as follows.

Theorem 2.1. Let $b \in \mathcal{B}$. We have for any $R>0$

$$
\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0, R]} B_{e^{b}} \chi_{[0, R]}\right)=\exp \left(R c_{1}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)+c_{2}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)+c_{3}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)\right) Q_{R}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& c_{1}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)=\dot{b}(0) \\
& c_{2}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)=-\frac{\nu}{2} b(0) \\
& c_{3}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)=\frac{1}{2} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} x(\dot{b}(x))^{2} d x \\
& Q_{R}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)=\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[R, \infty)} W_{e^{b_{-}}} B_{e^{-b}} W_{e^{b_{+}}} \chi_{[R, \infty)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

There exists a constant $C>0$ such that for any $R \geq 1$ and $b \in \mathcal{B}$ the following estimate holds

$$
\left|Q_{R}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)-1\right| \leq \frac{C e^{4\left\|b_{+}\right\|_{L_{\infty}}}}{\sqrt{R}} L(b) \exp \left(\frac{C e^{4\left\|b_{+}\right\|_{L_{\infty}}}}{\sqrt{R}} L(b)\right)
$$

where

$$
L(b)=\left(1+\left\|x b^{\prime}(x)\right\|_{L_{\infty}}^{2}+\|b\|_{\mathcal{B}}^{2}\right)\|b\|_{\mathcal{B}}
$$

Remark. Let us again mention cases $\nu= \pm 1 / 2$. Substituting $B_{b}=W_{b} \mp H_{b}$ into the formula for $Q_{R}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)$ we obtain that it is equal to

$$
Q_{R}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)=\operatorname{det}\left(I \mp \chi_{[R, \infty)} H_{e^{b_{-}}-b_{+}} \chi_{[R, \infty)}\right)
$$

We have used the following facts:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& W_{e^{-b}}=W_{e^{-b_{-}}} W_{e^{-b_{+}}}, \quad W_{e^{b_{ \pm}}}=e^{W_{b_{ \pm}}} \\
& W_{e^{b_{-}}} H_{e^{-b_{+}}} W_{e^{b_{+}}}=H_{e^{b_{-}-b_{+}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

For the first two identities see Section 6. For the last see [5, Section II]. Indeed, the expression for remainder (2.3) coincides with the one obtained by Basor, Ehrhardt and Widom in [5, Formula (3)]

We now proceed to the corollary for the determinanal point process with the Bessel kernel $\mathbb{P}_{J_{\nu}}$ (see Section 5). Let $\overline{S_{f}^{R}}=S_{f}^{R}-\mathbb{E}_{J_{\nu}} S_{f}^{R}$. By $F_{R, f}$ and $F_{\mathcal{N}}$ we denote cumulative distribution functions of $\overline{S_{f}^{R}}$ and the standard Gaussian respectively.

Theorem 2.2. Let $b \in \mathcal{B}$ be a real-valued function, satisfying $c_{3}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)=1 / 2$. Then there exists a constant $C=C\left(L(b),\left\|b_{+}\right\|_{L_{\infty}}\right)$ providing the following estimate for the Kolmogorov-Smirnov distance for any $R \geq 1$

$$
\sup _{x}\left|F_{R, b}(x)-F_{\mathcal{N}}(x)\right| \leq \frac{C}{\ln R}
$$

# 3 Structure of the paper 

Let us first recall the result of Basor and Chen.
Theorem 3.1. For $f \in H_{1}(\mathbb{R}) \cap L_{1}(\mathbb{R})$ we have

$$
\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0, R]} W_{e^{\hat{f}}} \chi_{[0, R]}\right)=\exp \left(R c_{1}^{S}(f)+c_{2}^{S}(f)\right) Q_{R}^{S}(f)
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& c_{1}^{S}(f)=\hat{f}(0) \\
& c_{2}^{S}(f)=\frac{1}{2} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} x \hat{f}(x) \hat{f}(-x) d x \\
& Q_{R}^{S}(f)=\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[R, \infty)} W_{e^{\hat{f}-}} W_{e^{-\hat{f}+}} W_{e^{-\hat{f}-}} W_{e^{\hat{f}+}} \chi_{[R, \infty)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark. We state Theorem 3.1 under different conditions than in [2] for a clearer outline of proof of Theorem 2.1.

The proof consists of three main steps.
Step 1. Wiener-Hopf factorization properties give the following identity

$$
\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0, R]} W_{e^{\hat{f}}} \chi_{[0, R]}\right)=e^{R c_{1}^{S}(f)} \operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0, R]} W_{e^{-\hat{f}+}} W_{e^{\hat{f}}} W_{e^{-\hat{f}-}} \chi_{[0, R]}\right)
$$

Step 2. It will be shown that the operator $W_{e^{-\hat{f}+}} W_{e^{\hat{f}}} W_{e^{-\hat{f}-}}$ is of determinant class. Apply the Jacobi-Dodgson identity: $\operatorname{det}(P A P)=\operatorname{det}(A) \operatorname{det}\left(Q A^{-1} Q\right)$ for orthogonal projections $P, Q$, satisfying $P+Q=I$, and determinant class invertible $A$. We have

$$
\frac{\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0, R]} W_{e^{-\hat{f}+}} W_{e^{\hat{f}}} W_{e^{-\hat{f}-}} \chi_{[0, R]}\right)}{\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[R, \infty)} W_{e^{\hat{f}-}} W_{e^{-\hat{f}+}} W_{e^{-\hat{f}-}} W_{e^{\hat{f}+}} \chi_{[R, \infty)}\right)}=\operatorname{det}\left(W_{e^{-\hat{f}+}} W_{e^{\hat{f}}} W_{e^{-\hat{f}-}}\right)
$$

where $W_{e^{\hat{f}}}^{-1}=W_{e^{-\hat{f}+}} W_{e^{-\hat{f}-}}$, as follows from the properties of the Wiener-Hopf factorization.
Step 3. From properties of the Fredholm determinant and Wiener-Hopf factorization we have $\operatorname{det}\left(W_{e^{-\hat{f}+}} W_{e^{\hat{f}}} W_{e^{-\hat{f}-}}\right)=\operatorname{det}\left(W_{e^{\hat{f}-}} W_{e^{\hat{f}+}} W_{e^{-\hat{f}-}} W_{e^{-\hat{f}+}}\right)$. The Widom formula (see [27]) states that the last determinant is well-defined and its value is

$$
\operatorname{det}\left(W_{e^{\hat{f}-}} W_{e^{\hat{f}+}} W_{e^{-\hat{f}-}} W_{e^{-\hat{f}+}}\right)=e^{c_{2}^{S}(f)}
$$

This finishes the proof.
We now pass to the proof of our main result, Theorem 2.1.
Lemma 3.2. For $b \in H_{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right) \cap L_{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)$we have

$$
\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0, R]} B_{e^{b}} \chi_{[0, R]}\right)=e^{R c_{1}^{B}(b)} \operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0, R]} W_{e^{-b_{+}}} B_{e^{b}} W_{e^{-b_{-}}} \chi_{[0, R]}\right)
$$

It is not known if $W_{e^{-b_{+}}} B_{e^{b}} W_{e^{-b_{-}}}-I$ is trace class, so the Jacobi-Dodgson identity cannot be applied directly. However, one can observe that the equality (3.2) means that the ratio of the determinants in the left-hand side does not depend on $R$. In our case we can use an analogue of the Jacobi-Dodgson identity (Corollary 8.2) to show the independence of the ratio from $R$.

Lemma 3.3. Let $b \in H_{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right) \cap L_{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)$and $\chi_{[R, \infty)}\left(B_{e^{-b}}-W_{e^{-b}}\right) \chi_{[R, \infty)}$ be a trace class operator for any $R>0$. Then there exists $Z(b)$ such that for any $R>0$ we have

$$
\frac{\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0, R]} W_{e^{-b}+} B_{e^{b}} W_{e^{-b}-} \chi_{[0, R]}\right)}{\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[R, \infty)} W_{e^{b}-} B_{e^{-b}} W_{e^{b}+} \chi_{[R, \infty)}\right)}=Z(b)
$$

Observe that the denominator in (3.5) equals $Q_{R}^{B}(b)$. The central step in the proof of Theorem 2.1 is the following.

Lemma 3.4. For $b \in L_{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right) \cap L_{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)$such that $\|b\|_{\dot{B}}<\infty$ and $z \in \mathbb{C}$ we have that $\chi_{[R, \infty)}\left(B_{b+z}-\right.$ $\left.W_{b+z}\right) \chi_{[R, \infty)}$ is trace class for any $R>0$. There exists a constant $C$ such that for any $R \geq 1$, $z \in \mathbb{C}$ and $b$ satisfying conditions above we have

$$
\left\|\chi_{[R, \infty)}\left(B_{b+z}-W_{b+z}\right) \chi_{[R, \infty)}\right\|_{\mathcal{J}_{1}} \leq \frac{C}{\sqrt{R}}\|b\|_{\dot{B}}
$$

The operator $Q_{R}^{B}(b)$ is related to the operator in (3.4) by the formula (8.5) below. This allows to obtain the estimate (2.2). Further, the asymptotic for the numerator in (3.5) follows from Lemma 3.2 and the asymptotic result of Basor and Ehrhardt (see Theorem 8.4). This proves that $Z(b)=\exp \left(c_{2}^{B}(b)+c_{3}^{B}(b)\right)$.

The rest of the paper has the following structure. In Section 4 we recall some facts and notation for trace class and Hilbert-Schmidt operators. Then in Section 5 we explain relation between the Fredholm determinant in Theorem 2.1 and determinantal point process with the Bessel kernel. In Section 6 we prove properties of the Wiener-Hopf factorization and deduce Lemma 3.2. Section 7 presents the proof of Lemma 3.4. We conclude the proof of Theorems 2.1 and 2.2 in Section 8.

# 4 Trace class and Hilbert-Schmidt operators 

In this section we recall certain theorems for symmetrically-normed ideals. Here and below by $\mathcal{J}_{1}$ and $\mathcal{J}_{2}$ we denote the ideals of trace class and Hilbert-Schmidt operators respectively. For the basic definitions we refer the reader to [24] and [22]. Let $E$ be $\mathbb{R}$ or $\mathbb{R}_{+}=[0, \infty)$.
Definition 1. The operator $K$ on $L_{2}(E)$ is locally trace class if for any bounded measurable subset $B \subset E$ the operator $\chi_{B} K \chi_{B}$ is trace class. Let $\mathcal{J}_{1}^{\text {loc }}\left(L_{2}(E)\right)$ stand for the space of locally trace class operators.

Recall that for $K \in \mathcal{J}_{1}$ the Fredholm determinant $\operatorname{det}(I+K)$ is well defined. It is continuous with respect to the trace norm. We also define the regularized determinant as follows

$$
\operatorname{det}_{2}(I+K)=\exp (-\operatorname{Tr}(K)) \operatorname{det}(I+K)
$$

The introduced function is continuous with respect to the Hilbert-Schmidt norm. It is then extended by continuity to all Hilbert-Schmidt operators.

The following theorem implies that for a function $f \in L_{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right) \cap L_{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}_{+}\right)$the determinants $\operatorname{det}\left(I+\chi_{[0, R]} B_{f} \chi_{[0, R]}\right), \operatorname{det}\left(I+\chi_{[0, R]} W_{f} \chi_{[0, R]}\right)$ are well defined.
Theorem 4.1 ( [22, Theorem 3.11.9]). Let $K$ be a continuous kernel on $[a, b]^{2}$ and induce a positive self-adjoint operator $K$ on $L_{2}[a, b]$. Then the operator $K$ is trace-class. In addition, for any trace class $K$ with continuous kernel we have

$$
\operatorname{Tr}(K)=\int_{a}^{b} K(x, x) d x
$$

We will refer to formula (4.1) as to calculation of trace over the diagonal.
Recall that the kernel of an integral operator is defined almost everywhere on $[a, b]^{2}$. Thus, if we change a kernel, satisfying conditions of Theorem 4.1 on the diagonal, the formula (4.1) may fail. This explains the continuity requirement. Let us now extend the class of kernels, for which the formula (4.1) holds.

Let $K$ be a self-adjoint trace class operator. By the Hilbert-Schmidt theorem we have the spectral decomposition, that is its kernel can be chosen in the form

$$
K(x, y)=\sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} \lambda_{i} \phi_{i}(x) \phi_{i}^{*}(y)
$$

where $\left\{\phi_{i}\right\}_{i \in \mathbb{N}}$ forms an orthonormal basis. Now by definition the trace is equal to

$$
\operatorname{Tr}(K)=\int_{a}^{b} \sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} \lambda_{i} \phi_{i}(x) \phi_{i}^{*}(x) d x
$$

which is equal to $\int_{a}^{b} K(x, x) d x$ if we choose $K$ as in (4.2). Observe that this does not require the kernel to be continuous, but the choice of the kernel holds up to values on subsets of $[a, b]^{2}$ having zero measure projections. Also observe that for a function $f \in L_{\infty}[a, b]$ the kernel of the operator $f K$ can be chosen as

$$
(f K)(x, y)=\sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} \lambda_{i}\left(f(x) \phi_{i}(x)\right) \phi_{i}^{*}(y)
$$

and its trace equals $\int_{a}^{b} f(x) K(x, x)$. We will use these observations in the following section.
We will also employ the following theorem.
Theorem 4.2 ([15, Theorem 2.2]). For $A, B \in \mathfrak{B}(\mathcal{H})$ having a trace class commutator we have that $e^{A} e^{B} e^{-A-B}-I$ is trace class. For the determinant we have

$$
\ln \operatorname{det}\left(e^{A} e^{B} e^{-A-B}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{Tr}([A, B])
$$

# 5 Application to the determinantal point process with the Bessel kernel 

Let $E$ be $\mathbb{R}$ or $\mathbb{R}_{+}=[0, \infty)$. Recall that a configuration on $E$ is a not more than countable subset of $E$ without accumulation points. We denote the set of configurations by $\operatorname{Conf}(E)$. It is endowed with certain $\sigma$-algebra of measurable subsets $\mathfrak{X}$ (see [25]). A point process $\mathbb{P}$ is defined to be a probability measure on $(\operatorname{Conf}(E), \mathfrak{X})$.

For a configuration $X \in \operatorname{Conf}(E)$ and a measurable function $f: E \rightarrow \mathbb{C}$ define additive and multiplicative functionals by the following formulae respectively

$$
\begin{gathered}
S_{f}(X)=\sum_{x \in X} f(x) \\
\Psi_{1+f}(X)=\prod_{x \in X}(1+f(x))
\end{gathered}
$$

Point processes induce respective random variables.

Definition 2. A point process $\mathbb{P}_{K}$ on $\operatorname{Conf}(E)$ is determinantal if there exists an operator $K \in$ $\mathcal{J}_{1}^{\text {loc }}\left(L_{2}(E)\right)$, satisfying the following condition for any bounded measurable function $f$ with compact support $B=\operatorname{supp} f$

$$
\mathbb{E}_{K} \Psi_{1+f}=\operatorname{det}\left(I+f K \chi_{B}\right)
$$

We consider the limit distribution of $S_{f}^{R}=S_{f(x / R)}$ as $R \rightarrow \infty$ for the determinantal point process with the Bessel kernel $\mathbb{P}_{J_{\nu}}$ [26] on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$, induced by operator $B_{\chi_{[0,1]}}$.

Theorem 3.1 describes the considered limit for the sine process $\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{S}}$ on $\mathbb{R}$, induced by operator $\mathcal{F}^{-1} \chi_{[-\pi, \pi]} \mathcal{F}$ on $L_{2}(\mathbb{R})$. To be precise, we formulate the following statement.
Proposition 5.1. We have for $f \in L_{1}(E) \cap L_{\infty}(E)$

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbb{E}_{J_{\nu}} \Psi_{1+f}^{R}=\operatorname{det}\left(I+\chi_{[0, R]} B_{f} \chi_{[0, R]}\right) \\
\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{S}} \Psi_{1+f}^{R}=\operatorname{det}\left(I+\chi_{[0,2 \pi R]} W_{f} \chi_{[0,2 \pi R]}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

The Laplace transform of additive functionals is expressed via multiplicative functionals by the following formula

$$
\mathbb{E} e^{\lambda S_{b}^{R}}=\mathbb{E} \Psi_{e^{\lambda b}}^{R}
$$

Therefore Proposition 5.1 implies that it is equal to the Fredholm determinant $\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0, R]} B_{e^{\lambda b}} \chi_{[0, R]}\right)$ for the Bessel kernel determinantal point process and $\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0,2 \pi R]} W_{e^{\lambda b}} \chi_{[0,2 \pi R]}\right)$ for the sine process.

In order to prove Proposition 5.1 we follow Bufetov [13, Section 2.9] and extend the formula (5.1). Let $K$ be a Hilbert-Schmidt self-adjoint operator on $L_{2}(E)$. Choose the kernel $K$ to coincide with its spectral decomposition (see Section 4). Define the extended Fredholm determinant as follows

$$
\operatorname{det}(I+K)=\exp \left(\int_{E} K(x, x) d x\right) \operatorname{det}_{2}(I+K)
$$

Before diving into calculations we give several inequalities for $b$. Firstly, the Cauchy-BunyakovskySchwarz inequality implies the following

$$

The same argument for derivative gives

$$
\left|b^{\prime}(t)\right| \leq \sqrt{t}\left(\left|b^{\prime}(0)\right|+\|b\|_{\dot{H}_{2}}\right)

Further, using inequality (7.17) we have

$$

Lastly, observe the identity

$$
\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{b_{0}(t)}{t}\right)=\frac{1}{t^{2}}\left(\int_{0}^{t} b^{\prime}(x) d x-b_{0}(t)+\int_{0}^{t} x b^{\prime \prime}(x) d x\right)=\frac{1}{t^{2}} \int_{0}^{t} x b^{\prime \prime}(x) d x

The Cauchy-Bunyakovsky-Schwarz inequality implies $\left|\int_{0}^{t} x b^{\prime \prime}(x) d u\right| \leq t^{3 / 2}\|b\|_{\dot{H}_{2}}$. This inequality with the expression above yield

$$
\left|\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{b_{0}(t)}{t}\right)\right| \leq \frac{\|b\|_{\dot{H}_{2}}}{\sqrt{t}}

$$

$$
\begin{aligned}

$$

\end{aligned}
$$

where the limit in infinity is zero by Lemma 7.5. These calculations imply the following estimate for the derivative for $x, y \geq 1$

$$
\left|\partial_{y} \mathcal{R}_{1}(x, y)\right| \leq \frac{2}{(x+y)^{2}}\left(\left|b^{\prime}(0)\right|+\left\|b^{\prime \prime}\right\|_{L_{1}}+\left\|t b^{\prime \prime \prime}(t)\right\|_{L_{1}}\right)

$$
\left\|\chi_{[R, \infty)} \mathcal{R}_{1} \chi_{[R, \infty)}\right\|_{\mathcal{J}_{1}} \leq \frac{C\|b\|_{\dot{\mathcal{B}}}}{\sqrt{R}}

# 2. Estimate for $S$ 

Using estimate (7.7) we get

$$

$$
\left\|\chi_{[R, \infty)} S \chi_{[R, \infty)}\right\|_{\mathcal{J}_{1}} \leq 2 C_{\nu}^{2} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{\left|b_{0}(t)\right|}{t} G(t R) d t

$$

Again Proposition 7.1 together with estimate (7.7) give

$$

$$

$$

\left\|\chi_{[R, \infty)} T_{0} \chi_{[R, \infty)}\right\|_{\mathcal{J}_{1}} \leq \frac{2 C C_{\nu}}{\sqrt{R}}\left(\left|b^{\prime}(0)\right|+\|b\|_{\dot{H}_{1}}+\|b\|_{\dot{H}_{2}}\right) \leq \frac{4 C C_{\nu}}{\sqrt{R}}\|b\|_{\dot{\mathcal{B}}}

Denote the respective operator by $\tilde{Z}$. Integrate its kernel by parts as follows

$$
\begin{aligned}

$$
\left\|\chi_{[R, \infty)} \tilde{Z} \chi_{[R, \infty)}\right\|_{\mathcal{J}_{1}} \leq \frac{\left|A_{\nu}\right|\|b\|_{\dot{B}}}{R}+\frac{\left|A_{\nu}\right|}{R} \int_{0}^{\infty}\left|\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{b_{0}(t)}{t}\right)\right| d t

Therefore, we conclude the following estimate

$$
\left\|\chi_{[R, \infty)} \tilde{Z} \chi_{[R, \infty)}\right\|_{\mathcal{J}_{1}} \leq \frac{5\left|A_{\nu}\right|\|b\|_{\dot{\beta}}}{R}

This finishes the proof of Lemma 3.4.

$$

where $c_{i}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)$ are given as in Theorem 2.1.

Clearly assumptions of Theorem 2.1 are more restrictive by Lemma 7.5. The following lemma establishes that $b \in \mathcal{B}$ is sufficient for $e^{-b}$ to satisfy conditions of Lemma 3.4.

Lemma 8.5. Let $b \in \mathcal{B}$. Then we have that $e^{b}-1 \in L_{1} \cap L_{\infty}$. There exists a constant $C$ such that for any $b \in \mathcal{B}$ we have

$$
\left\|e^{b}\right\|_{\mathcal{B}} \leq C e^{\|b\|_{L_{\infty}}}\left(1+\left\|x b^{\prime}(x)\right\|_{L_{\infty}}^{2}+\|b\|_{\mathcal{B}}^{2}\right)\|b\|_{\mathcal{B}}
$$

Proof. The first statement follows directly from $L_{\infty}$ being a Banach algebra with pointwise multiplication and

$$
\left\|e^{b}-1\right\|_{L_{1}} \leq\|b\|_{L_{1}}\left\|\frac{e^{b}-1}{b}\right\|_{L_{\infty}}
$$

For the estimate we immediately have

$$
\left\|e^{b}\right\|_{\dot{H}_{1}} \leq e^{\|b\|_{L_{\infty}}}\|b\|_{\dot{H}_{1}}
$$

The third derivative of $e^{b}$ is

$$
\left(e^{b}\right)^{\prime \prime \prime}=e^{b}\left(b^{\prime \prime \prime}+\left(b^{\prime}\right)^{3}+3 b^{\prime} b^{\prime \prime}\right)
$$

Observe that

$$
\left\|b^{\prime}\right\|_{L_{\infty}} \leq\|\lambda \dot{b}(\lambda)\|_{L_{1}} \leq\|b\|_{\dot{H}_{1}}+\|b\|_{\dot{H}_{2}}
$$

This yields the following estimate

$$
\left\|e^{b}\right\|_{\dot{H}_{3}} \leq e^{\|b\|_{L_{\infty}}}\left(\|b\|_{\dot{H}_{3}}+\|b\|_{\mathcal{B}}^{2}\|b\|_{\dot{H}_{1}}+3\|b\|_{\mathcal{B}}\|b\|_{\dot{H}_{2}}\right)
$$

We next write the second derivative of $x e^{b(x)}$

$$
\left(x e^{b(x)}\right)^{\prime \prime}=e^{b(x)}\left((x b(x))^{\prime \prime}+x\left(b^{\prime}(x)\right)^{2}\right)
$$

Therefore the following estimate holds

$$
\left\|x e^{b(x)}\right\|_{\dot{H}_{2}} \leq e^{\|b\|_{L_{\infty}}}\left(\|x b(x)\|_{\dot{H}_{2}}+\left\|x b^{\prime}(x)\right\|_{L_{\infty}}\|b\|_{\dot{H}_{1}}\right)
$$

The third derivative of $x^{2} e^{b(x)}$ is

$$
\left(x^{2} e^{b(x)}\right)^{\prime \prime \prime}=e^{b(x)}\left(6 x\left(b^{\prime}(x)\right)^{2}+3 x^{2} b^{\prime}(x) b^{\prime \prime}(x)+\left(x^{2} b(x)\right)^{\prime \prime \prime}+x^{2}\left(b^{\prime}(x)\right)^{3}\right)
$$

This implies that

$$
\left\|x^{2} e^{b(x)}\right\|_{\dot{H}_{3}} \leq e^{\|b\|_{L_{\infty}}}\left(3\left\|x b^{\prime}(x)\right\|_{L_{\infty}}\|x b(x)\|_{\dot{H}_{2}}+\left\|x^{2} b(x)\right\|_{\dot{H}_{3}}+\left\|x b^{\prime}(x)\right\|_{L_{\infty}}^{2}\|b\|_{\dot{H}_{1}}\right)
$$

Proof of Theorem 2.1. Recall the following inequality

$$
|\operatorname{det}(I+K)-1| \leq\|K\|_{\mathcal{J}_{1}} \exp \left(\|K\|_{\mathcal{J}_{1}}\right)
$$

Also for any trace class operator $A$ and bounded $B$ we have $\|A B\|_{\mathcal{J}_{1}} \leq\|A\|_{\mathcal{J}_{1}}\|B\|$. By the definition of Wiener-Hopf operators we have $\left\|W_{b}\right\|=\|b\|_{L_{\infty}}$. These facts and Lemmata 3.4, 8.5 with expression (8.5) prove the estimate (2.2).

For the derivation of $Z(b)$ observe that the denominator in expression (3.5) approaches one by the argument above. From Lemma 3.2 and Theorem 8.4 we have for the numerator in (3.5)

$$
\operatorname{det}\left(\chi_{[0, R]} W_{e^{-b_{+}}} B_{e^{b}} W_{e^{-b} \ldots} \chi_{[0, R]}\right) \rightarrow \exp \left(c_{2}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)+c_{3}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)\right), \quad \text { as } R \rightarrow \infty
$$

It is now clear that $Z(b)=\exp \left(c_{2}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)+c_{3}^{\mathcal{B}}(b)\right)$. This finishes the proof.

We now proceed to the proof of Theorem 2.2. Firstly we establish an estimate for the speed of convergence of the expectation of $S_{f}^{R}$. The argument is based on proof of Proposition 5.1 in [3].

Lemma 8.6. There exists a constant $C$ such that for any $b \in \mathcal{B}$ we have

$$
\left|\mathbb{E}_{J_{\nu}} S_{f}^{R}-\left(\hat{b}(0)-\frac{\nu}{2} b(0)\right)\right| \leq \frac{C\|b\|_{\dot{R}}}{\sqrt{R}}
$$

Proof. The expression for expectation of additive functional is

$$
\mathbb{E}_{J_{\nu}} S_{f}^{R}=\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} f(x / R) B_{\chi_{[0,1]}}(x, x) d x
$$

Recall that the Bessel kernel $B_{\chi_{[0,1]}}(x, y)$ is defined on the diagonal by the following formula

$$
B_{\chi_{[0,1]}}(x, x)=\frac{x}{2}\left(J_{\nu}^{2}(x)-J_{\nu+1}(x) J_{\nu-1}(x)\right)
$$

The asymptotic of the diagonal as $x \rightarrow \infty$ is

$$
B_{\chi_{[0,1]}}(x, x)=\frac{1}{\pi}+\frac{\sin \left(2\left(x-\phi_{\nu}\right)\right)}{x}+O\left(x^{-2}\right)
$$

This implies that the following function is well defined

$$
F(\xi)=-\int_{\xi}^{\infty}\left(\frac{t}{2}\left(J_{\nu}^{2}(t)-J_{\nu+1}(t) J_{\nu-1}(t)\right)-\frac{1}{\pi}\right) d t
$$

It is clear that $F(\xi)=O\left(\xi^{-1}\right)$ as $\xi \rightarrow \infty$. We therefore have $|F(\xi)| \leq C(1+\xi)^{-1}$ for some constant $C$. We use $F$ for integration by parts

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} f(x / R) B_{\chi_{[0,1]}}(x, x) d x-\left.\frac{1}{\pi} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} f(x / R) d x=\left.f(x / R) F(x)\right|_{0} ^{\infty}-\right. \\
& -\frac{1}{R} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} f^{\prime}(x / R) F(x) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

where by Lemma 7.5 we have $f(\infty) F(\infty)=0$. For the value in zero we write using $J_{\nu-1}(t)+$ $J_{\nu+1}(t)=\frac{2 \nu}{t} J_{\nu}(t)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& F(0)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{t}{2}\left(J_{\nu}^{2}(t)-J_{\nu+1}(t) J_{\nu-1}(t)\right)-\frac{1}{\pi}\right) d t= \\
& =\int_{0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{t}{2}\left(J_{\nu}^{2}(t)+J_{\nu+1}^{2}(t)\right)-\frac{1}{\pi}\right) d t-\nu \int_{0}^{\infty} J_{\nu+1}(t) J_{\nu}(t) d t
\end{aligned}
$$

The second integral is equal to $1 / 2$ (see [17, Sect. 6.512-3]). For the first term use the following integral

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{T} x J_{\nu}^{2}(x) d x=\frac{T^{2}}{2}\left(J_{\nu}^{2}(T)-J_{\nu+1}(T) J_{\nu-1}(T)\right)= & \\
& =\frac{T}{\pi}+\sin \left(2\left(T-\phi_{\nu}\right)\right)+o(1) \quad \text { as } T \rightarrow \infty
\end{aligned}
$$

Recall that $\phi_{\nu+1}=\phi_{\nu}+\frac{\pi}{2}$. Therefore the term is zero. We conclude that $F(0) b(0)=\frac{\nu}{2} b(0)$.
What is left to do is estimate the second term in (8.8). Using $F(\xi) \leq C(1+\xi)^{-1}$ we can write

$$
\left|\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} f^{\prime}(x) F(R x) d x\right| \leq \int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}} \frac{C\left|b^{\prime}(x)\right|}{1+R x} d x
$$

which is at most $\frac{C\|b\|_{\Omega_{1}}}{\sqrt{R}}$. This completes the proof.
Proof of Theorem 2.2. Recall that by $F_{R, b}$ and $F_{\mathcal{N}}$ we denoted cumulative distribution functions of additive functionals $\widetilde{S}_{b}^{R}$ and standard Gaussian $\mathcal{N}(0,1)$ respectively. Using the Feller smoothing estimate (see $[16$, p. 538]), Theorem 2.1 and Proposition 5.1 we have for any $T>0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sup _{x}\left|F_{R, b}-F_{\mathcal{N}}\right| \leq \frac{24}{\sqrt{2 \pi^{3}} T}+ \\
& \qquad+\frac{1}{\pi} \int_{-T}^{T} \frac{1}{|k|}\left|e^{i k R \tilde{b}(0)-i k \frac{\kappa}{2} b(0)-i k \mathbb{E}_{, t_{\nu}} S_{b}^{R}} Q_{R}^{R}(k b)-1\right| d k
\end{aligned}
$$

By the second statement of Theorem 2.1 and Lemma 8.6 the expression under the integral may be estimated by the following expression for some $C>0$, depending only on $\left\|b_{+}\right\|_{L_{\infty}}$ and $L(b)$

$$
\frac{C}{\sqrt{R}}\left(1+|k|^{2}\right) \exp \left(\frac{C|k|}{\sqrt{R}}\left(1+|k|^{2}\right) e^{C|k|}\right)
$$

Observe that if $|k| \leq C_{1} \ln R$, where $C_{1} C<1 / 2$, then there exists a constant $\widetilde{C}$ such that for any $R \geq 1$ the expression above is at most

$$
\frac{\widetilde{C}\left(1+(\ln R)^{2}\right)}{\sqrt{R}}
$$

Therefore if we choose $T=C_{1} \ln R$ then the integral in (8.9) is at most

$$
\frac{2 \widetilde{C} C_{1} \ln R\left(1+(\ln R)^{2}\right)}{\sqrt{R}}
$$

And the statement of the theorem follows.

abstract:
We consider a family of linear operators, diagonalized by the Hankel
transform. The Fredholm determinants of these operators, restricted to $L_2[0,
R]$, are expressed in a convenient form for asymptotic analysis as
$R\to\infty$. The result is an identity, in which the determinant is equal to
the leading asymptotic multiplied by an asymptotically small factor, for which
an explicit formula is derived. We apply the result to the determinantal point
process with the Bessel kernel, calculating the speed of the convergence of
additive functionals with respect to the Kolmogorov-Smirnov metric.
